Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Preoperative Physical Therapy Education for Total Joint Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: 126 patients undergoing unilateral TKA or THA were randomised into two groups

Participants.evidence: patients undergoing unilateral TKA or THA were randomised into two groups at a single institution

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group (n = 63) received preopPTEd, while the control group (n = 63) received no further education.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluated the effect of a one-time, one-on-one preoperative physical therapy education session coupled with a web-based microsite (preopPTEd) on patients’ readiness to discharge from physical therapy (PT), length of hospital stay, and patient-reported functional outcomes after total joint arthroplasty.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was readiness to discharge from PT, measured by the number of postoperative inpatient PT visits.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between February and June 2015, 126 patients undergoing unilateral TKA or THA were randomised into two groups

Number_Analysed.evidence: The intervention group (n = 63) received preopPTEd, while the control group (n = 63) received no further education.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The preopPTEd group had fewer postoperative inpatient PT visits (mean, 3.3; 95% CI, 3.0-3.6) and achieved readiness to discharge faster (mean, 1.6 days; 95% CI, 1.2-1.9) than the control group.
